#Text=3 .
#Text=Results and Discussion
#Text=3.1 .
#Text=Comparisons of Normalization Results
#Text=This section presents the normalization results of the proposed algorithm and then compares them with the results of a conventional algorithm .

#Text=First , our proposed normalization process is performed step-by-step for the experimental images , in which the radiometric resolution is compressed to 8-bits , and the spectral indices of the blue , green , red , and NIR bands are selected as ExG , COM , ExGR , and ExG , respectively .

#Text=Subsequently , the results of our proposed method are compared with the conventional methods ( MS , NC , histogram matching , and random forest ( RF ) ) to evaluate them visually and quantitatively , and
#Text=Figure 6
#Text=,
#Text=Figure 7
#Text=and
#Text=Figure 8
#Text=show the results for each experimental image .
#Text=From the overall visual inspection , the normalization of the proposed method is shown to be better than that of the conventional methods .
#Text=MS and NC , which are regression-based methods , assume that the relationship between the subject and reference images is linear .
#Text=However , as shown in the results , neither the phenological properties nor the radiometric properties are normalized .
#Text=In other words , it can be confirmed that it is not appropriate to assume a linear relationship in the case of high-resolution images , in which vegetation changes exist .
#Text=In the case of histogram matching , it is a representative nonlinear normalization method , which is based on global statistical information .
#Text=Overall , the radiometric properties are normalized , while the normalization for the phenological properties is not performed at all .
#Text=That is , when only statistical information is used , it is possible to normalize the radiometric properties , but there is a limit to phenological normalization .

#Text=RF is a nonlinear method that is performed through RF regression , which uses neighbor information-based features , such as the mean , variance , and gray-level co-occurrence matrix as the training input values .
#Text=The results of this method show that the radiometric and phenological normalizations are performed , but spectral distortion is present .
#Text=Furthermore , blurriness occurs in the results due to the neighbor information-based features , which results in some loss of detail , especially on linear objects .
#Text=On the other hand , our proposed method shows that the radiometric and phenological normalizations are properly performed , and there is no spectral distortion or blurriness in the results .

#Text=To verify the radiometric and phenological normalization results in detail , some regions are selected and enlarged , with red rectangles representing the built-up areas and green rectangles representing the vegetation areas .
#Text=Figure 9
#Text=shows built-up areas , which represent the radiometric properties , consist of roads and the roofs of buildings , and the enlarged areas for each normalization result .

#Text=For roads , the proposed method normalizes the radiometric properties in such a way that the image is the closest in consistency with the reference image , while , in the case of roofs , the results vary for the site .

#Text=For site 2 , showing a relatively large roof , the radiometric properties normalized through the proposed method show the most similarity with those of the reference image , whereas for site 3 , showing several small roofs , the proposed method displays some turbidity when compared to other methods .
#Text=In other words , roofs are affected by their objective size , which is judged according to its geometric distortion .

#Text=Large-sized objects can be trained properly , even in the presence of geometric distortion , while small-sized objects acquire the characteristic of other surrounding objects , which adversely affects training .
#Text=For vegetation areas , phenological properties , such as forests , grass , and crops , are included , and
#Text=Figure 10
#Text=shows the corresponding enlarged areas .

#Text=In the case of forests , it is confirmed that the areas without vegetation due to the phenological properties in the subject image are normalized to the same phenological properties as the reference image at all sites .

#Text=For grass and crops , the performance of normalization is somewhat less than that for forests due to the heterogenous characteristics , but it contains the characteristics of the reference image as a whole .
#Text=Although visual inspection is a straightforward and direct manner of comparison , it is highly subjective ; thus , quantitative evaluations of each method are further performed based on NRMSE .

#Text=The NRMSE is defined as in Equations ( 12 ) and ( 13 ) : ( 12 ) ( 13 ) where is RCSSs in the normalized image of band ; is the RCSSs in the reference image of band ; is the total number of RCSSs ; and , is the mean of RCSSs in the reference image of band i .
#Text=Table 3 shows the NRMSE for the results of the proposed method and the conventional methods .
